awd_titl_txt: BIGDATA: F: IA: Robust Convolutional Modeling for Massive-Scale Electron Microscopy Data
awd_abstract_narration:
Microscopy is a pillar of modern science, which enables us to understand, inspect and improve on nature. While the technology of modern microscopes has progressed by leaps and bounds in the past decades, the methods used by microscopists to analyze data remain primitive. Common to new and emerging modalities of microscopy is the generation of massive, multi-dimensional data sets. This project develops fundamental analysis tools to extract basic motifs from these datasets; in particular, from data produced by scanning tunneling microscopes. These analysis tools will transform microscopy imaging by improving the quality and statistical significance of atomic-scale observations of materials.  Key analysis goals that will be addressed include guarantees that algorithms produce models which accurately reflect the physics of the material of interest, and that algorithms perform reliably on practical data which may contain noise and errors. Key experimental goals include the generation of large scale data sets from multiple microscopy modalities which will be used to test and extend the analysis tools.

The project leverages recent advances in high-dimensional nonconvex optimization to address fundamental challenges in convolutional data modeling, the problem of modeling data as superpositions of translated motifs. Because the goal is to produce accurate information about novel materials whose properties are not yet understood, the investigators seek algorithms which exhibit (i) guaranteed performance,(ii) robustness to gross errors and (iii) scalability to massive, high-dimensional datasets. Building on recent progress in dictionary learning, the investigators study the properties of efficient methods for recovering models with one or more motifs. They seek highly scalable algorithms for these problems, using Riemannian optimization and active set methods. They study variants which are robust to commonly occurring gross errors, including pixel and scanline corruption, and contrast variations. The algorithms are applied to study materials for which previous analysis methodologies fail, including materials with multiple types of defects, quasiparticle interference, and high temperature superconductors. For each of these materials, high resolution scanning tunneling microscopy and spectroscopic imaging will be performed to produce large-scale, multidimensional data sets. Data sets on well-studied materials will be used to test and verify analysis algorithms, and the application of these algorithms to data sets on novel materials will be used to transform our understanding of the electronic structure of complex materials. Data sets on other microscopy modalities will also be obtained to generalize analysis tools to multiple scales in space, time and energy.

por.por_cntn:
Microscopy is a fundamental tool for studying the natural world, with implications on fundamental physics, material science, chemistry, biology and neuroscience. Microscopy data are typically structured: data in many areas of microscopy can be modelled as superpositions of basic repeated motifs. Classical approaches to studying this structure are based on manual analyses, or inspection of fixed transformations such as the Fourier transform. As datasets and modalities proliferate, there is a need for tools that can automatically identify these fundamental motifs. At a technical level, this motivates the study of tools for convolutional data modeling and analysis. This raises technical challenges: optimization problems arising in convolutional data modeling are nonconvex, and until recently there was a lack of guaranteed methods for these problems. The project pursued a program of data modeling (with an emphasis on electron microscopy data), algorithm development and theoretical analysis, with the goal of producing robust tools for analyzing structures in real datasets.

 

The basic challenges in convolutional data modeling come from symmetry: models involving a single motif exhibit a signed shift symmetry; models involving multiple motifs exhibit both permutation and shift symmetries. Because of these symmetries, optimization problems in convolutional modeling are nonconvex, with multiple global minima and a complicated collection of critical points. Theoretical results developed in the project show that symmetry is the key to understanding this landscape: under certain modeling hypotheses, local minimizers are symmetric copies of the truth, and all other critical points exhibit strict negative curvature in symmetry breaking directions. In this situation, it is possible to provably obtain global minimizers using efficient methods. This analysis articulates fundamental tradeoffs in convolutional modeling (sparsity vs. motif coherence) and highlights the key role of constraints (the sphere) in creating problems that can be solved globally. The project leveraged these theoretical advances to give new practical, efficient methods for deconvolution and related convolutional data modeling problems.

 

In the domain of electron microscopy, the project developed convolutional models and algorithms which fundamentally improve over classical approaches, based on the modulus of the Fourier transform. The classical approach suffers from a ``problem of phase?? which leads to increasingly poor estimates as samples become more densely populated, and completely breaks down when samples contain multiple motifs (multiple defect signatures). In contrast, the algorithms developed in the project provably handle densely overlapping motifs, and extend in a natural way to samples containing multiple motifs. 

 

The developed algorithms were applied to dense data sets of scanning tunneling microscopy on the iron pnictide superconductor NaFeAs. Using the developed algorithm, we were successfully able to recover phase sensitive quasiparticle interference data on the optimally doped superconductor. This data in turn was used to extract the symmetry of the superconducting gap and prove that it is s+- symmetry, a major advance in the field.The findings of the project also lead to new models and algorithms for other microscopy modalities (fluorescence microscopy, chemical microscopy) and for other domains, including astronomy and neuroscience.
